key_points.title: Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs) üéØ
key_points.content: Sophisticated, long-term attacks by skilled adversaries. **How to understand it:** Like a spy operation‚Äîattackers gain access and remain hidden for months or years. **Characteristics:** Stealthy (avoid detection), Persistent (remain for long time), Targeted (specific organization), Multi-stage (complex attack chain). **Real-world:** An APT group targets a company, gains initial access through phishing, establishes foothold, moves laterally, steals data over months. Detection requires advanced techniques because they avoid traditional security tools. **Best practice:** Behavioral analysis, Threat intelligence, Network monitoring, Endpoint monitoring, Threat hunting, Incident response.

key_points.title: Zero-Day Attack Detection üö®
key_points.content: Detecting attacks using unknown vulnerabilities. **How to understand it:** Like detecting a new type of crime that hasn't been seen before. **Challenge:** No signatures available, Unknown attack patterns, Must rely on behavior. **Detection methods:** Behavioral analysis (unusual activity), Anomaly detection (deviations from normal), Sandboxing (isolated execution), Threat intelligence (emerging threats). **Real-world:** A zero-day exploit is used in an attack. Traditional antivirus doesn't detect it (no signature). Advanced detection tools identify unusual behavior: process spawning, network connections, file modifications. Attack is detected and blocked. **Best practice:** Behavioral monitoring, Anomaly detection, Sandboxing, Threat intelligence, Rapid response, Patch management.

key_points.title: User and Entity Behavior Analytics (UEBA) üë§
key_points.content: Analyzing user and device behavior to detect threats. **How to understand it:** Like profiling‚Äîyou learn normal behavior and detect when someone acts differently. **How it works:** Baseline normal behavior, Detect anomalies, Identify suspicious patterns, Alert on deviations. **Real-world:** UEBA monitors user behavior and detects: employee accessing files at 3 AM (unusual time), from foreign country (unusual location), accessing sensitive data (unusual access). This indicates potential account compromise. **Best practice:** Establish baselines, Monitor continuously, Tune detection, Reduce false positives, Investigate anomalies, Integrate with SIEM.

key_points.title: Threat Intelligence and Indicators üîç

Security team configures SIEM to alert on these IOCs. When IOCs appear in logs, alerts are triggered, and threats are detected. **Best practice:** Use multiple intelligence sources, Automate IOC detection, Update intelligence regularly, Correlate with internal data, Share intelligence, Act on intelligence.

key_points.title: Threat Hunting üé£
key_points.content: Proactively searching for threats in your environment. **How to understand it:** Like a security guard actively patrolling, not just watching cameras. **Process:** Hypothesis (what to look for), Investigation (search for indicators), Analysis (analyze findings), Response (act on threats). **Real-world:** Threat hunter hypothesizes: 'Attackers may be using PowerShell for lateral movement.' They search logs for PowerShell activity, find suspicious commands, investigate, and discover active attack. Threat is detected before it causes damage. **Best practice:** Regular threat hunting, Use threat intelligence, Develop hypotheses, Search systematically, Document findings, Improve detection.

key_points.content: Gathering digital evidence for investigation. **Evidence types:** Disk images (complete copies of storage), Memory dumps (RAM contents), Log files (system, application, network), Network captures (packet captures), Files (documents, executables), Email (communications). **How to understand it:** Like collecting evidence at a crime scene‚Äîyou gather everything that might be relevant. **Real-world:** A security incident occurs.
